prompt_text:
Draft a journalist-ready press release announcing the launch of [PROGRAM NAME] by [ORGANIZATION NAME].

The press release should:
- Be 450–550 words; follow AP style; use people-first, plain language; short paragraphs (1–3 sentences); no exclamation points or jargon.
- Use this order: Headline; Optional subhead; “For Immediate Release” or “Embargoed until [EMBARGO DATE/TIME TZ]”; Dateline (CITY, State — Month Day, Year); Lead; Body; Quotes; Call-to-action/assets; Boilerplate; Media contact.
- Write a headline (8–12 words) in active voice that includes [CITY/REGION] or a compelling [LOCAL HOOK]/stat; avoid puns/colons.
- Include release/embargo line and dateline as above.
- Lead paragraph answers who/what/when/where/why/how: name [PROGRAM NAME], [LAUNCH DATE], [LOCATION/ONLINE], [PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES], [PROBLEM STAT], expected change, and scope (serve X people in Y timeframe).
- Body (P2–P3): convert [PROGRAM DETAILS: 3–5 BULLETS] into concise sentences; include [PARTNERS], funding if relevant, and one [SUPPORTING STAT/STATISTIC + SOURCE] with hyperlink; tie to [LOCAL HOOK].
- Quote 1 (25–40 words) from [ED NAME, TITLE] on [ED QUOTE THEME]; specific and human (no “we’re excited”); include one vivid outcome or detail.
- Optional Quote 2 (20–30 words) from [PARTNER SPOKESPERSON] or [BENEFICIARY FIRST NAME—with consent]; respectful, people-first.
- Call to action for media: interview/site visit timing, [CALL TO ACTION], [PHOTO/ASSET LINKS], [WEBSITE URL]; plus a 6–9 word email subject line and a 2–3 sentence pitch tailored to [MEDIA TARGETS].
- Boilerplate (75–100 words): [ONE-SENTENCE MISSION], core programs, geography, annual reach (# served), year founded, website.
- Media contact: [CONTACT NAME], [CONTACT TITLE], [CONTACT EMAIL], [CONTACT PHONE].
- Tone: [TONE = FORMAL (neutral, reporter-ready) / WARM (community-centered, plain) / CONVERSATIONAL (local-friendly, approachable)]; no byline—attribute quotes to speakers.

A strong release is newsy (not promotional), local, and concrete: quantify goals, timelines, and beneficiaries; attribute stats; avoid clichés (“transformative,” “world-class”), acronyms, and savior language. Center community impact and dignity. If any bracketed detail is missing, ask up to three quick clarifying questions before drafting.

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

**South Side Blocks Get Fresh Food Access with New Fridge Network**

CHICAGO, Illinois — May 28, 2024 — The Southside Fresh Fridge Network, a new initiative by Bridgeview Community Table, launches on June 10, 2026. Ten solar-powered community fridges will offer fresh produce and staples across Englewood, Bronzeville, and Woodlawn. Low-income families, seniors, and transit-limited residents on the South Side will benefit. Reliable access to fresh food is scarce and expensive in several South Side neighborhoods, forcing long trips and skipped meals. This network is expected to serve 7,500 people monthly in its first year, providing essential food resources. An interactive map of fridge locations is available at bridgeviewtable.org/fridges.

Many South Side blocks are over two miles from a full-service grocery store. Cook County’s food insecurity rate was 13.5% in 2022. The Southside Fresh Fridge Network will install and stock 15 solar-powered fridges with fresh produce, dairy, and other essential items, monitored daily by local volunteers. The program also features weekly nutrition pop-ups offering simple, low-cost recipes using culturally familiar ingredients. Additionally, Bridgeview Community Table coordinates bulk purchasing with small corner stores to reduce prices on fresh items by up to 20%.

The initiative provides stipends and safety training for resident “Fridge Stewards” at each site, empowering community members. A transparent dashboard will track inventory, uptime, and usage by ZIP code. Key partners include the Greater Chicago Food Depository, St. Bernard Hospital, the Chicago Park District, and Bronzeville Community Garden.

Marisol Vega, Executive Director of Bridgeview Community Table, emphasized the program's community-driven nature. “This is neighbor-powered dignity. It means people can skip a long bus trip for groceries and find fresh food right on their block,” Vega said. “I’ve seen a Fridge Steward restock oranges and milk just before school lets out, knowing kids will grab healthy snacks on their way home.”

Dr. Aaron Whitaker, Community Health Director at St. Bernard Hospital, highlighted the direct health benefits. “Access to nutritious food is fundamental to well-being. This network helps build a healthier community, one fridge at a time.”

**MEDIA INVITATION**

Media are invited to a kickoff and site visit at 9 a.m. on June 10 at the Kennedy-King College parking lot. Please contact press@bridgeviewtable.org to request interviews, a ride-along with Fridge Stewards, or a media kit.

**Assets:**
High-resolution photos: https://bit.ly/southsidefridge-photos
B-roll footage: https://bit.ly/southsidefridge-broll
Website: https://bridgeviewtable.org

**Email Subject Lines & Pitches:**

**Block Club Chicago:** South Side Community Fridges Launch for Food Access
**Pitch:** Bridgeview Community Table launches a solar-powered fridge network across the South Side, bringing fresh food directly to neighborhoods. We invite you to cover this new community-led initiative that aims to reduce food insecurity.

**WBEZ:** New Fridge Network Expands South Side Food Access
**Pitch:** Learn how the Southside Fresh Fridge Network is addressing food deserts in Englewood, Bronzeville, and Woodlawn. This story includes local residents acting as Fridge Stewards and provides a model for community-driven food solutions.

**Chicago Tribune — South:** Fresh Food Comes to South Side Neighborhoods
**Pitch:** Many South Side blocks are over two miles from a grocery store. This new network of community fridges is changing that by offering fresh produce and staples, supported by local partners and volunteers.

**Hyde Park Herald:** Bridgeview Debuts Fresh Fridges in South Side
**Pitch:** Your readers will be interested in the new Southside Fresh Fridge Network, particularly its impact on Woodlawn residents. We can arrange interviews with local Fridge Stewards and partners.

**Chicago Sun-Times:** Bringing Fresh Food Closer to South Side Homes
**Pitch:** Bridgeview Community Table is launching a significant effort to combat food insecurity on the South Side with its new fridge network. This initiative provides dignity and reliable access to fresh food for thousands of residents.

**About Bridgeview Community Table**
Bridgeview Community Table partners with South Side neighbors to expand reliable, dignified access to fresh, affordable food close to home. Our core programs include community fridges, healthy eating workshops, and strategic partnerships with local businesses to increase food accessibility. We serve thousands of residents annually across Englewood, Bronzeville, and Woodlawn, fostering health and community resilience. Founded in 2018, Bridgeview Community Table is committed to empowering communities through food. bridgeviewtable.org

**Media Contact:**
Lena Ortiz
Communications Manager
press@bridgeviewtable.org
312-555-0198
